channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saskatchewan Stabbing Spree Kills at Least 10
item.description: The police identified two suspects in attacks that took place along a wide area of a Cree Nation Indigenous reservation and a nearby village in Saskatchewan Province.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Yonette Joseph and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer at the scene of a stabbing in Weldon, Saskatchewan on Sunday.

item.title: Chile Voters Reject New, Left-Leaning Constitution
item.description: The rejected constitution would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enshrined more than 100 constitutional rights, a global record.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating the rejection of the proposed constitution in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday.

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Vow Economic Relief, Fearing Unrest
item.description: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A protest in Prague on Saturday against the Czech government and its response to the energy crisis.

item.title: Blame, Hate and License Plates in a Divided Kosovo Town
item.description: Tensions between ethnic Albanians and ethnic Serbs have flared in recent months, stoked by a bureaucratic dispute over vehicle tags, testimony to the region’s toxic identity politics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Armend Nimani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Serbian flag in the ethnically Serb northern part of Mitrovica, Kosovo. Violent ethnic animosity has largely subsided, but tensions are bubbling up again.

item.title: Vietnam’s Plan for Loudspeaker Broadcasts Meets Resistance
item.description: The city of Hanoi may revive regular loudspeaker broadcasts, which were routine before most people had TVs or internet access. Residents are wary of bringing them back.
item.dc:creator: Chau Doan and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loudspeakers in front of shops in Hanoi, Vietnam, late last month.

item.title: Hamas Executes 5 Palestinians in Gaza, Officials Say
item.description: The Gaza Interior Ministry said that three of the executions were carried out by hanging and the other two by firing squad.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The executions were the first reported in Gaza in a half-decade and occurred amid anxiety within Hamas.

item.title: China Threatens Reaction After U.S. Announces Arms Sales to Taiwan
item.description: A $1.1 billion package would “severely jeopardize” ties, Chinese officials say in demanding that Washington revoke the deal.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers during a live-fire drill in Pingtung, Taiwan, last month. The Biden administration just approved the sale of more than $1.1 billion worth of arms to Taiwan.

item.title: In South Korea, a Hit Show Brings Autism Into the Spotlight
item.description: “Extraordinary Attorney Woo” has raised awareness of autism in South Korea, where developmental disabilities are still a taboo subject for many people.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Teaching a child at Autism Partnership Korea, a center for young children with autism in Seoul.

item.title: How Shady Ships Use GPS to Evade International Law
item.description: A technology enabling the transmission of fake locations to carry out murky or even illegal business operations could have profound implications for the enforcement of international law.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reliable, left, a ship registered in Cyprus, taking on oil at a refinery in Venezuela. The oil tanker has transmitted fake location coordinates to circumvent international laws and sanctions.

item.title: Shelling Persists in East Despite Shift in Focus to South
item.description: An uptick in fighting in southern Ukraine has changed the calculus for both sides in the eastern Donetsk region. Germany unveiled its largest measures yet to help citizens deal with soaring energy costs.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed market after a Russian strike in Kramatorsk, in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: As Britain Prepares for a New Leader, Tensions With Allies Loom
item.description: Comments from the front-runner for prime minister, Liz Truss, suggest bumpier relations with Europe and the U.S. if she wins, with Northern Ireland getting in the way of the “special relationship.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Liz Truss addressed Conservative Party members last week in London. The outcome of the party’s vote for prime minister will be announced on Monday.

item.title: Militants Attack Trucks Carrying Food Relief in Somalia
item.description: The attack in central Somalia comes even as the country faces a devastating drought that has left almost half its population hungry.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The scene of a hotel attack in Mogadishu, Somalia, last month. The attack on food supplies on Saturday came just two weeks after Al Shabab carried out a 30-hour siege on the hotel in the Somali capital, killing 21 people and injuring 117 others.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Rajapaksa Returns Home, Just Weeks After Being Ousted
item.description: Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s fall from grace had seemed to end a powerful dynasty, but his arrival in the country’s capital, Colombo, shows how deeply entrenched his family is.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: The motorcade of Gotabaya Rajapaksa, Sri Lanka’s former president, as he returned to Colombo, the capital, early Saturday.

item.title: Explosion Kills 7 Police Officers in Colombia
item.description: Dozens of police officers have been killed in the country so far this year, as its new president struggles to quell a wave of violence he campaigned on ending.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky

item.title: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Colorado River. There’s a Model to Avert the Worst.
item.description: Success in the Yakima River Basin in Washington holds lessons for the seven states at war over water in the American West.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Shakespeare or Bieber? This Canadian City Draws Devotees of Both
item.description: For nearly 70 years, Stratford, Ontario, has attracted legions of theater fanatics to its Shakespeare festival. About a dozen years ago, a very different type of pilgrim began arriving: Beliebers.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cutout of Justin Bieber in the Stratford Perth Museum. The setting is meant to replicate the steps of the city’s Avon Theater.

item.title: Typhoon Hinnamnor: South Korea Braces for Storm’s Arrival
item.description: The storm, expected to make landfall on Tuesday, could be the strongest in the country’s recorded history. Japan and China were also making preparations.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: High waves hit the southern coast of Jeju Island, South Korea, on Monday as the typhoon approached.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Support for European energy costs.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Ukrainians in Rural Ireland Piece Together New Lives, Step by Step
item.description: With 50,000 Ukrainians now finding sanctuary in Ireland, the largest number of refugees the country has ever accepted is merging with locals in homogeneous rural villages.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian woman minding a child at a hostel that hosts Ukrainian families on Arranmore Island, Ireland.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Europe’s Energy Protections
item.description: Plus Chileans vote on a new constitution and rickshaws lead India’s electric vehicle transition.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Pipes at the landfall facilities of the ‘Nord Stream 1’ gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany, in March.

item.title: John Sullivan, the U.S. Ambassador to Russia, Leaves Moscow to Retire
item.description: John Sullivan managed the U.S. embassy during its most difficult period in decades — when Moscow forced hundreds of employees to leave and after Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: John J. Sullivan served as deputy secretary of state in the Trump administration before being appointed ambassador to Russia in December 2019.

item.title: Germany Announces $65 Billion Relief Package Amid Soaring Inflation
item.description: Berlin aims to ease the burden on citizens facing soaring inflation and surging energy costs that have worsened with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, at a news conference on Sunday, promised that “no one will be left behind” as soaring costs hurt consumers.

item.title: Office Drama
item.description: Labor Day has become a flash point for big companies who want workers to return to the office.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: Credit Karma requires their employees to work part of the week in person, but allows them to pick which days.

item.title: Russia’s Unfounded Claims of Secret U.S. Bioweapons Linger On and On
item.description: Without providing evidence, the Kremlin is pressing allegations that the U.S. operates labs in Ukraine and beyond. This week, it has called an investigative session in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia at a student event last week. The Kremlin accuses the United States of operating secret biological research programs to wreak havoc around the globe.

item.title: How Russia Relies on Old Tech in Weapons Aimed at Ukraine
item.description: Investigators who examined the electronics in Russia’s newest cruise missiles and attack helicopters were surprised to find decades-old technology reused from earlier models.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay

item.title: A 9-year-old boy is killed in a rocket attack in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Trails left by Russian rockets could be seen from the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv on Saturday.

item.title: Renewed Shelling Puts Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant at Risk
item.description: The decision to keep monitors at the plant despite the obvious risks underscored what the International Atomic Energy Agency’s leader called the “unprecedented” peril of the moment.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A delegation from the International Atomic Energy Agency, returning from an inspection of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, at a Ukrainian-controlled checkpoint.

item.title: Chile Votes on Constitution That Would Enshrine Record Number of Rights
item.description: In a single ballot on Sunday, Chileans will decide on abortion, universal health care, rights for nature and a record expansion of constitutional rights.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Copies of the proposed constitution were handed out last week in Constitution Square, in front of La Moneda, where the president’s offices are housed.

item.title: E.U. Says It Can Endure Winter Without Russian Gas Supply
item.description: The European Union economy minister said the bloc was “well prepared” to resist efforts by Moscow to disrupt its energy supply.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: New energy-saving regulations came into effect on Sept. 1 in Germany, stating that most public buildings can only be heated to 66 degrees Fahrenheit and cannot be externally lit after 10 p.m.

item.title: Game On
item.description: It’s Labor Day weekend, the perfect time to try — you guessed it — pickleball.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: How Many Drinks a Week Are Safe? Canada Considers a Much Lower Limit
item.description: Research to update Canada’s drinking guideline has found that there are no health benefits, only dangers, from alcohol.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Research has found that consuming more than six drinks per week greatly increases health risks.

item.title: Abortion Pill Providers Work to Broaden Access Post-Roe Decision
item.description: These new efforts, which test the legal boundaries, have sprung up since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and many states restricted abortion.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Kelly Burgess for The New York Times
item.media:description: New medication abortion services are springing up and existing services are expanding, some adopting new practices that increase access while pushing the envelope of regulations and laws.

item.title: At Mikhail Gorbachev’s Funeral, Russians Mourn in Silent Protest
item.description: At the funeral of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, the size of the crowds signaled the depth of the regret about the undoing of the freedoms that his tenure initiated.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Honor guards standing next to the coffin of Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday at the House of the Unions in Moscow.

item.title: Ukraine Struggles to Identify Bucha Massacre Victims, Five Months On
item.description: No longer able to defer burial, Ukrainian investigators are photographing unclaimed and unidentified bodies, taking DNA samples and assigning them numbers, hoping that one day their families will claim them.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cemetery workers carrying the coffin of an unidentified victim during a funeral last month for 15 people who died in March during the Russian occupation.

item.title: The Biden administration asks Congress for $13.7 billion in additional aid for Ukraine, underscoring its resolve.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces would receive new weaponry to bolster their aging Soviet-era artillery if the latest aid package proposed by the Biden administration passes in Congress.

item.title: Argentina Reels From Assassination Attempt on Its Vice President
item.description: The man who the authorities believe tried to shoot Cristina Fernández de Kirchner showed an interest in a mix of fringe ideologies, including the far right, his social media showed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Leonardo Coelho and David Feliba
item.media:description: Argentina’s vice president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, with her security detail outside her residence in Buenos Aires on Friday.

item.title: Hawaii Closes Its Last Coal-Fired Power Plant
item.description: A state law bans the use of coal for energy production beginning next year.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: The AES Hawaii Power Plant on Oahu supplied more than 11 percent of Hawaii’s electricity in 2021.

item.title: I.A.E.A. Head Warns of Grave Risk From Fighting Near Zaporizhzhia Plant
item.description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned that increased fighting near the Russian-occupied nuclear plant could cause an accident.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the I.A.E.A., and a team of inspectors visited the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on Thursday.

item.title: South African Villagers Win Suit to Halt Shell’s Oil Exploration
item.description: A judicial panel ruled the energy giant had not properly consulted local communities, possibly setting a broader precedent for challenges to offshore drilling activities.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: Residents along South Africa’s Wild Coast, like these fishermen landing a catch of sardines, came together to halt Shell Global’s prospecting in the area.

item.title: Iran Seizes, Then Releases Two U.S. Drones, Officials Say
item.description: The Navy called a similar incident this week “flagrant” and “unwarranted.”
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Iranian State Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image from Iranian state television shows Iranian sailors throwing an American sea drone overboard in the Red Sea on Thursday.

item.title: John Podesta to Oversee $370 Billion in U.S. Climate Spending
item.description: Mr. Podesta, a Democratic stalwart, will oversee $370 billion in clean energy investments. Gina McCarthy, the president’s domestic climate adviser, is stepping down.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Podesta was a top adviser to President Barack Obama, chief of staff to President Bill Clinton and campaign chairman for Hillary Clinton.

item.title: Gina McCarthy, Biden’s Top Climate Adviser, to Step Down Sept. 16
item.description: As the country’s first national climate adviser, Ms. McCarthy helped seed climate policy throughout the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy previously served as E.P.A. administrator in the Obama administration and had environmental roles under Republican governors.

item.title: Against Fierce Resistance, Ukraine Makes Small Gains in the South
item.description: Stepping up an offensive in the region near Kherson, Ukraine has retaken small villages. But officials predict a brutal winter ahead.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier and his fellow tank crew members returning to their frontline position in July after completing a mission in Ukraine’s Kherson region.

item.title: Join Al Gore and John Kerry for a Times Climate Event
item.description: How does climate change exacerbate other global challenges? Join us remotely or in person for our climate event series, with an upcoming gathering in New York in September.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Blast at Afghan Mosque Kills at Least 18, Including a Pro-Taliban Cleric
item.description: Among the casualties was Mawlawi Mujib Rahman Ansari, who had ties to the Taliban and was known for his criticism of the country’s previous Western-backed governments.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: For years, Mawlawi Mujib Rahman Ansari had urged his supporters to carry out protests against Afghanistan’s pro-Western governments and had preached against women’s rights.

item.title: Kenya Awaits Supreme Court Ruling on Presidential Election
item.description: The Supreme Court is expected to rule by Monday on whether the recent election of William Ruto as president, now mired in a welter of conflicting accusations, should stand.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Kenya's Supreme Court hearing the day's submissions from counsel representing president-elect William Ruto, in Nairobi on Thursday.

item.title: A price cap on Russian oil wins the backing of G7 ministers.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: An oil field in Russia. Energy analysts are skeptical that a proposal to corral the price of Russian oil would be successful.

item.title: Myanmar’s Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Gets More Prison Time
item.description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the politician and Nobel laureate, was found guilty of election fraud on Friday, a sign that the junta has no intention of easing its pressure on her.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2018. She was sentenced to three more years in prison on Friday, bringing her total prison term to 20 years so far. For the first time, she was sentenced to hard labor.

item.title: The Serena Effect
item.description: An improbable run at what may be her final U.S. Open.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams defeated Anett Kontaveit and will face Ajla Tomljanovic in the third round of the U.S. Open on Friday.

item.title: Campaign in India Aims to Destigmatize Periods and Introduce Better Products
item.description: A campaign in India aims to end the shame and silence around monthly periods and to introduce better hygiene products.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj

item.title: ‘Magic in Her Hands.’ The Woman Bringing India’s Forests Back to Life
item.description: Tulsi Gowind Gowda has spent most of her more than 80 years planting and nurturing trees in southern India. “I like them more than anything else in my life,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tulsi Gowda has devoted her life to transforming barren land into dense forests in Karnataka, a state in southern India.

item.title: Chile Could Transform Indigenous Rights in Watershed Vote
item.description: The proposed constitution would enshrine some of the world’s most extensive Indigenous rights. But those reforms have become the focal point of the campaign to reject the new text.
item.dc:creator: Ana Lankes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dancing the traditional Mapuche “purrun” during a rally last week in support of the new constitution in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: The U.N.’s nuclear agency is limited in its ability to enforce its recommendations on Zaporizhzhia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: United Nations experts visiting the Russian-controlled Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in southern Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: President Biden speaks on democracy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Biden warned on Thursday against “a blind loyalty to a single leader and a willingness to engage in political violence.”

item.title: Behind the Scenes of an Afghan (Australian) Soccer Story
item.description: The story of a keeper and her teammates, as they fled and found new lives.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Afghan women’s soccer team before a game in Melbourne last year.

item.title: ‘Condemned to Lead’ Europe, German Chancellor Struggles for Impact
item.description: Facing its worst crisis since World War II, Europe is looking for leadership. Olaf Scholz is trying to take up the role, but faces a tepid response.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin this week.

item.title: Argentina’s Vice President Unharmed After Assassination Attempt
item.description: A man tried to fire a gun inches from the head of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s most prominent leader, but it did not go off.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Natalie Alcoba
item.media:description: Police officers arrested a man who pointed a firearm at Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner outside her home in Buenos Aires on Thursday.

item.title: Experts Brave Shelling to Reach Imperiled Ukrainian Nuclear Plant at Last
item.description: The team from the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog reached the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia plant for the first time since the war began, despite fresh shelling each side blamed on the other.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vehicles carrying International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors return to Ukrainian-held territory after visiting the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant on Thursday.

item.title: Zelensky says Russia prevented independent journalists from observing the I.A.E.A. mission.
item.dc:creator: Ron DePasquale
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director general of the I.A.E.A., Rafael M. Grossi, center, with the Ukrainian energy minister and the head of Energoatom, Ukraine’s nuclear energy agency, on Thursday after visiting the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant.

item.title: What’s Behind the Pileup of Sex Abuse Scandals?
item.description: Sociologists see a pattern that goes beyond the culture of specific schools, churches and industries: an ingrained resistance to self-policing or defying a community’s hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.media:description: The Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Salt Lake City, Utah.

item.title: Teenagers Died of Asphyxiation in South Africa Tavern, Parents Are Told
item.description: Health officials met with families that had waited more than two months to learn why 21 teenagers died one June night in an overcrowded bar.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The entrance to Enyobeni Tavern in Scenery Park, East London, South Africa. The deaths of the 21 teenagers have been called a national tragedy.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.N. Accuses China of Possible ‘Crimes Against Humanity’
item.description: Plus U.N. inspects an embattled nuclear power plant and China locks down Chengdu.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A security guard at a detention center in Yarkant County, Xinjiang, China, last year. Delays to the U.N. report about abuses in the region prompted fierce pushback from rights groups.
